name: saros
description: Saros is an IDE plugin for distributed collaborative software development
contribution_justification: https://www.saros-project.org/contribute/processes/development.html
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/saros-project/saros/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Installation: https://www.saros-project.org/documentation/installation.html
How to start/use it: https://www.saros-project.org/documentation/getting-started.html
documentation_interface_justification: Saros is a plug-in that does not provide external interface to be used by other projects.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: We add all (fine-grain) commits that have passed review in the master branch.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_semver_justification: Being and interactive tool (nothing else building on top of it), our users have no problem working with the most recent version, so we allow ourselves to break backwards compatibility in irregular intervals and not necessarily when the most functionality is being added. A convincing semantic version scheme is not obvious under these circumstances.
release_notes_justification: Each old release which is released via SourceForge contains a `README` file (or a version specific release note file) which contains the release notes. See here: https://sourceforge.net/projects/dpp/files/Saros
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly vulnerabilities.
test_justification: Our test codes resides in the same repository along with the production code.
test_invocation_justification: We use JUnit plus a special-purpose test framework called STF we have developed ourselves for the distributed GUI tests. STF is FLOSS as well.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project is not written in a memory-unsafe language.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests. Furthermore [Gitter](https://gitter.im/saros-project/saros) allows users and developers to discuss.
english_justification: Saros is an all-english language project.

name: ONAP Spike
description: ONAP Spike is a Microservice used to generate events describing changes to the graph data.
sites_https_justification: The project site support HTTPS using TLS (i.e. https://gerrit.onap.org/r/#/admin/projects/aai/spike)
contribution_justification: https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Development+Procedures+and+Policies
contribution_requirements_justification: https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Development+Procedures+and+Policies describes requirements for acceptable contributions and is linked from the AAI project page. https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Java+code+style shows java code style. https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Developer+Best+Practices
license_location_justification: https://gerrit.onap.org/r/gitweb?p=aai/spike.git;a=blob;f=License.txt;h=328acac0de747df41031afcb0ab5370c5390ab45;hb=refs/heads/master
floss_license_justification: Apache-2.0 The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://gerrit.onap.org/r/gitweb?p=aai/spike.git;a=blob;f=README.md;h=ce28311743928f684dc58544912f959b552d254a;hb=refs/heads/master
repo_public_justification: https://gerrit.onap.org/r/#/admin/projects/aai/spike
repo_track_justification: https://gerrit.onap.org/r/#/admin/projects/aai/spike,branches
repo_interim_justification: There are branches from previous releases: https://gerrit.onap.org/r/#/admin/projects/aai/spike,branches
repo_distributed_justification: Gerrit.
version_unique_justification: Release version is with format ${major}.${minor}.${patch} and will be updated accordingly for each release.
version_tags_justification: Each release is tagged within the Gerrit repository
report_process_justification: The description of the process can be found in the following URL: https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Tracking+Issues+with+JIRA
enhancement_responses_justification: The reported issues are being handled as soon as possible.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: The process on how to report a vulnerability can be found in https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/ONAP+Vulnerability+Management
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Private vulnerability reports are not supported.
build_common_tools_justification: Maven and npm are used to build the project
build_floss_tools_justification: Maven is under Apache 2.0 license. And NPM is licensed under The Artistic License 2.0
test_justification: The project uses junit to run the unit tests.
test_invocation_justification: Tests can be run, by running the command "mvn clean install"
tests_documented_added_justification: This is documented on our wiki: https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Code+Coverage+and+Static+Code+Analysis
warnings_fixed_justification: The application logs the relevant warnings.
warnings_strict_justification: Build systems run the compile with test flag enabled by default. So any failure in test cases will fail the ci and the merge request.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Still some vulnerabilities to fix based on Sonar report.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We disallow SHA-1 or other insecure cryptographic algorithms.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: For each pull request, the project needs to be built successfully before the Merge option becomes activated. The test will be run automatically during the building process as well. Once build successfully and all tests has past, the Merge option will be activated.
discussion_justification: https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Joining+the+ONAP+Technical+Community
crypto_used_network_justification: We use ssh2 internal to the cluster and TLS1.2+ for the external interfaces.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: We support TLS certification verification before exchange of private information.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: All packages are delivered either as an jar artifact or a docker image. Incase of maven artifacts, they can be removed using the pom file. In case of docker container. We can delete the container we dont want. Also control the orchestration in Kubernetes if you want to exclude certain docker images.
dco_justification: https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Development+Procedures+and+Policies describes requirements for acceptable contributions and is linked from the AAI project page. https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Java+code+style shows java code style. https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Developer+Best+Practices
governance_justification:
ONAP requires both a Developer Certificate of Origin (DCO), and a Contributor License Agreement (CLA).

https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Contribution+Agreements
code_of_conduct_justification: ONAP adheres to the Linux Foundation Code of Conduct, found at https://lfprojects.org/policies/code-of-conduct/
roles_responsibilities_justification:
The key roles in the project and their responsibilities are described at

https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Community+Offices+and+Governance

Current members are listed at

https://wiki.onap.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=8226539
access_continuity_justification: For AAI we have multiple committers and multiple contributes who are listed in https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Resources+and+Repositories#ResourcesandRepositories-ActiveandAvailableInventory All committers have access and rights to maintain the code base, approve and review incoming changes and release a new version of the artifact. This will let the project continue with minimal to no interruption if one person is incapacitated. Also this project is controlled by the linux foundation so we can add more committers if needed
bus_factor_justification: The project covered in this report have more than 2 persons who actively contribute and maintain code. https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Resources+and+Repositories#ResourcesandRepositories-ActiveandAvailableInventory
documentation_roadmap_justification: Road map for AAI can be found in https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/AAI+R3+Platform+Maturity?preview=%2F35523310%2F35523289%2FAAI+Roadmap+2018-01-05.pdf
documentation_architecture_justification: Architecture of AAI can be found in https://wiki.onap.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=1015836
documentation_quick_start_justification: Information on setting up ONAP can be found at https://onap.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guides/onap-developer/settingup/index.html
documentation_current_justification: Documentation is updated on a regular bases when needed.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: No user interfaces; the project site is configurable for font size/colors.
internationalization_justification: It is not applicable at this point in time as the software will only be used by technical people and not by general public
maintenance_or_update_justification: All major releases are tagged in gerrit and the artifacts are stored with the release information on onap.nexus. So we can access all old versions of the artifact. If and when a upgrade requires certain steps to be followed they are being added to the release documents as needed
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: Vulnerabilities can be reported using the link https://wiki.onap.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=6591711 Currently we dont have any vulnerabilities reported, but the wiki page explains on how to report a vulnerability and how to report anonymously if you do not want the credit for it.
coding_standards_justification: Google coding style is used in ONAP https://github.com/google/styleguide
build_standard_variables_justification: The application does not create native binaries.
build_preserve_debug_justification: The application does not create native binaries.
build_non_recursive_justification: The application does not create native binaries.
build_repeatable_justification: All releases are tagged in gerrit(git), and the builds are controlled using jenkins. By providing the git tag information the same image can be build over and over again with same bit-for-bit result.
installation_development_quick_justifica: All the components require only java and maven to begin with for a developer to quickly install and test it. Even for deployment using OOM and the right amount of resources, we can deploy the full AAI/ONAP suite in less than a day. The steps are documented in https://onap.readthedocs.io/en/latest/submodules/oom.git/docs/oom_quickstart_guide.html
external_dependencies_justification: External dependencies are controlled using the pom file, which can be found in the root folder for the projects
dependency_monitoring_justification: We use sonatype CLM https://nexus-iq.wl.linuxfoundation.org/ and https://sonar.onap.org
updateable_reused_components_justificati: External components are maintained through Maven. The user can get a list of all included components using the maven dependency tree and can update or reuse as they see fit
interfaces_current_justification: We choose free open source solutions in every case and choose up-to-date versions of the components.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: https://jenkins.onap.org - on every commit, a verification job runs which runs an automated test suite. The code check in cannot pass with out jenkins posting a +1 on the review.
regression_tests_added50_justification: We add tests in these cases.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: AAI is working toward additional coverage but lack of resources prevent us from acheiving it: https://sonar.onap.org
test_policy_mandated_justification: Contributing guide lines for development is recorded in https://wiki.onap.org/display/DW/Development+Procedures+and+Policies
implement_secure_design_justification: AAI strives to implement secure design principles. We encrypt data where possible, and run security scans on the code and its dependencies.
input_validation_justification: he project strives to validate all input
crypto_credential_agility_justification: Credentials are separate and can be replaced without code compilation.

name: libwebsockets
description: Lightweight C library for websockets, h1 and h2 webserving and other protocols.
contribution_justification: https://libwebsockets.org/git/libwebsockets/tree/READMEs/README.contributing.md
license_location_justification: https://libwebsockets.org/git/libwebsockets/tree/LICENSE
floss_license_justification:
LGPL2.1 + SLE
https://libwebsockets.org/git/libwebsockets/tree/LICENSE
documentation_basics_justification: https://libwebsockets.org/lws-api-doc-master/html/index.html
repo_public_justification:
https://libwebsockets.org/git/libwebsockets/tree
git clone https://libwebsockets.org/repo/libwebsockets
repo_track_justification:
git
https://libwebsockets.org/git/libwebsockets/log
repo_distributed_justification: git
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: There have been no official vuln reports in the last 6 months.
test_justification: Lws has its own internal test scripts released as floss, which run under CI
test_invocation_justification: The tests are made up of scripts and third-party FOSS tools like h2spec
test_most_justification: Coverage is over 50% measured using gcov
tests_are_added_justification: See https://libwebsockets.org/git/libwebsockets/patch?id=c6d4fa133bd6ab47d8b2b9c41e3bb06cdba0d804 adding travis test support for new dbus apis
warnings_justification: The default build process builds with -Wall -Werror and several parts of -Wextra
warnings_fixed_justification: -Werror enforces a zero-tolerance policy on warnings
warnings_strict_justification: "Maximally Strict" leads to things like unused function parameters breaking build... if the parameter is there to meet a function pointer prototype, that isn't a bug.  So we cherrypicked individual tests from -Wextra.
know_secure_design_justification: Lws has a privilege drop mechanism, and implements bytewise parsers and other schemes to foil network-based attackers.
know_common_errors_justification: Lws is tested on Coverity at intervals and before every release.
crypto_floss_justification: Both supported TLS libs are FOSS - OpenSSL and mbedTLS
crypto_keylength_justification: 4096-bit RSA is used throughout.  OpenSSL can be configured at runtime to disable weak cyphers (giving A+ on lws servers as SSL Labs)
crypto_working_justification: The examples default to best practice cyphers + key exchanges, for PFS ie, A+ at SSL Labs
crypto_pfs_justification: The examples default to best practice cyphers + key exchanges, for PFS ie, A+ at SSL Labs
crypto_password_storage_justification: Does not do this by default
delivery_mitm_justification: https + git over https (and ssh for devs)
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Any coverity issues fixed immediately and retested
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: Always done immediately they are reported and confirmed fixed by re-test
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The examples default to best practice cyphers + key exchanges, for PFS ie, A+ at SSL Labs
discussion_justification:
https://libwebsockets.org/mailman/listinfo/libwebsockets
https://libwebsockets.org/pipermail/libwebsockets/
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: Checks on CA trust, cert date and matching hostname provided by default
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: Nothing generated before TLS tunnel is authenticated
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
access_continuity_justification: There is a backup maintainer in place the last several years with full github rights already.
documentation_quick_start_justification:
lws has around 40 buildable "minimal examples" for various scenarios

https://libwebsockets.org/git/libwebsockets/tree/minimal-examples
documentation_current_justification:
Doxygen creates API documentation... all other documentation like readmes

https://libwebsockets.org/git/libwebsockets/tree/READMEs

are in-tree, so the docs match the revision.
internationalization_justification: It's a library that doesn't generate text itself generally.
maintenance_or_update_justification: There are vX.Y-stable branches kept for each release.  At least the last one of these gets backported fixes from master that are periodically released as tags vX.Y.Z
build_non_recursive_justification: one-level cmake for lib, then no-cross-dependent independent cmake project for examples
installation_standard_variables_justific: cmake supports DESTDIR at the Makefile and other controls over install location at cmake level.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Everything goes in /usr/local prefix by default, which is standard
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Supports dynamic linking to all components, so distro libs are the default.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Travis runs about 1500 tests per build; build breaks if any failures.

name: PostgreSQL
description:
PostgreSQL is a powerful, open source object-relational database system that uses and extends the SQL language combined with many features that safely store and scale the most complicated data workloads. The origins of PostgreSQL date back to 1986 as part of the POSTGRES project at the University of California at Berkeley and has more than 30 years of active development on the core platform.

PostgreSQL has earned a strong reputation for its proven architecture, reliability, data integrity, robust feature set, extensibility, and the dedication of the open source community behind the software to consistently deliver performant and innovative solutions. PostgreSQL runs on all major operating systems, has been ACID-compliant since 2001, and has powerful add-ons such as the popular PostGIS geospatial database extender. It is no surprise that PostgreSQL has become the open source relational database of choice for many people and organisations.

Getting started with using PostgreSQL has never been easier - pick a project you want to build, and let PostgreSQL safely and robustly store your data.

https://www.postgresql.org/about/
contribution_justification: https://wiki.postgresql.org/wiki/Submitting_a_Patch#Patch_review_and_commit
license_location_justification: https://git.postgresql.org/gitweb/?p=postgresql.git;a=blob;f=COPYRIGHT;hb=HEAD
floss_license_justification:
https://www.postgresql.org/about/licence/
https://opensource.org/licenses/postgresql
documentation_basics_justification: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/
repo_public_justification: https://git.postgresql.org/gitweb/?p=postgresql.git;a=summary
repo_distributed_justification: Project uses git: https://git.postgresql.org/gitweb/?p=postgresql.git;a=summary
version_semver_justification:
Earlier versions of PostgreSQL used to use something roughly SemVer like, but it confused too many users, and caused arguments about when to increase the major versions. We now use a single major + minor versioning scheme:
https://www.postgresql.org/support/versioning/
release_notes_vulns_justification: CVEs are referenced in the release notes, see e.g. https://www.postgresql.org/docs/devel/static/release-10-5.html
report_tracker_justification: A mailing list is used, https://www.postgresql.org/list/pgsql-bugs/ .  This is unlikely to change in the short-term.
report_responses_justification: Traffic for https://www.postgresql.org/list/pgsql-bugs/ indicates that the vast majority of bugs are responded to.
enhancement_responses_justification: Traffic for https://www.postgresql.org/list/pgsql-bugs/ and https://www.postgresql.org/list/pgsql-hackers/ indicates that the vast majority of bugs / feature requests / patch submissions are responded to.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
Security vulnerability contact details are listed at https://www.postgresql.org/support/
See also https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/bug-reporting.html
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Security vulnerability contact details are listed at https://www.postgresql.org/support/ - this includes an email address to submit details to privately, but without email encryption.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Security response process is private, therefore unfortunately no URL about it is available.
test_justification: make check, make check-world execute tests, more tests are executed when configure is invoked with --enable-tap-tests.
test_invocation_justification:
make check invokes the testsuite, which is as much of a standard as available for C based projects.

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/devel/static/regress-run.html
test_most_justification: While coverage is not perfect, the vast majority of SQL commands are tested.
test_policy_justification:
There's a steady stream of test changes in https://git.postgresql.org/gitweb/?p=postgresql.git;a=history;f=src/test;hb=HEAD
There's additional testsuites in other directories.
tests_documented_added_justification:
Documentation could be better, but the contribution guides reference tests:
https://wiki.postgresql.org/wiki/Submitting_a_Patch#Patch_review_and_commit
https://wiki.postgresql.org/wiki/Developer_FAQ#How_do_I_test_my_changes.3F
https://wiki.postgresql.org/wiki/Regression_test_authoring
warnings_fixed_justification: Sensible warnings are usually very quickly spotted and fixed.  Warnings for odd systems (i.e. old compilers with bad diagnostics) sometimes not quite as fast.
warnings_strict_justification:
https://git.postgresql.org/gitweb/?p=postgresql.git;a=blob;f=configure.in;h=23b5bb867bbe1e858b60624e86bf499a475ae7e0;hb=HEAD#l481

Warnings that we found are helpful are enabled, others that tend not to be helpful are disabled.
crypto_published_justification: We largely rely on OpenSSL, and have additionally implemented scram support.
crypto_call_justification: Most cryptography is implemented using OpenSSL, but SCRAM (RFC 7677, 5802) is implemented by ourselves.
crypto_keylength_justification: No keys are generated by PostgreSQL itself (outside of tests).
crypto_pfs_justification: PostgreSQL relies on OpenSSL, which provides PFS.
crypto_password_storage_justification: scram-sha-256 (see RFC 7677) is supported in recent releases, but not the default configuration.
crypto_random_justification: OpenSSL's random number generator, Window's CryptoAPI, Linux's /dev/urandom are used in that order (depending on compilation settings, not using next after failure).
delivery_mitm_justification: TLS encryption with certificate verification is available.
delivery_unsigned_justification: No such functionality exists in PostgreSQL.
static_analysis_justification: Coverity is run regularly on an automated basis, other tools are run manually.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Valgrind is run automatically after commits.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Valgrind is run automatically after commits.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: There's a lot of assertions in the code.
discussion_justification: https://www.postgresql.org/list/
crypto_used_network_justification: TLS 1.3 is supported via new enough versions of OpenSSL, but not required by default.  Usually PostgreSQL is not directly exposed to the internet, for some sites the overhead of using encryption internally is prohibitive.
crypto_tls12_justification: TLS 1.3 is supported via new enough versions of OpenSSL.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
documentation_architecture_justification: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/devel/static/internals.html and a lot of per-subsystem READMEs etc exist.
documentation_current_justification:
Per version documentation exists and is of a high quality:
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: No GUI tools are included as part of PostgreSQL, the command-line tools are mostly usable with screenreaders etc.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: The CVEs listed under https://www.postgresql.org/support/security/ reference the reporter of the vulnerability, where desired by the reporter.
build_standard_variables_justification: autoconf is used, and environment / argument CC, CFLAGS, CXX, CXXFLAGS, and LDFLAGS are all respected.
build_preserve_debug_justification: The PostgreSQL build-system does not strip binaries. Debugging information can be enabled by passing --enable-debug to configure.
installation_standard_variables_justific: autoconf style ./configure --prefix (and other more granular flags) are available. DESTDIR is supported too, and used by tests.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Project can be tested from within the source code directory or installed into a desirable user-specified directory.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Most external dependencies are optional, the few embedded ones (e.g. tzdata) can be configured to instead use the system copy. Updates to embedded projects are made regularly.
interfaces_current_justification: We try hard not to rely on any deprecated APIs outside of archaic architectures / operating systems.
input_validation_justification: Input is properly parsed, with input validation, including correct encoding.
contributors_unassociated_justification: https://www.postgresql.org/community/contributors/ - Major Contributors work for different companies.
copyright_per_file_justification:
Each (non-generated) source code file has a header like:
/*-------------------------------------------------------------------------
 *
 * postgres.c
 *	  POSTGRES C Backend Interface
 *
 * Portions Copyright (c) 1996-2018, PostgreSQL Global Development Group
 * Portions Copyright (c) 1994, Regents of the University of California
 *
 *
 * IDENTIFICATION
 *	  src/backend/tcop/postgres.c
 *
 * NOTES
 *	  this is the "main" module of the postgres backend and
 *	  hence the main module of the "traffic cop".
 *
 *-------------------------------------------------------------------------
 */
two_person_review_justification: Every major change is expected to be reviewed, minor bugfixes, fixups etc sometimes are directly committed by more experiences committers. Casual contributors do not have commit access.
